docs.lead_paragraph: After a $76 million renovation, the 67-year-old former office building at 99 John Street opened two weeks ago as the latest addition to the housing stock in Manhattan's financial district. The 28-story Art Deco structure, which fills half the block front between Gold and Cliff Streets, contains 442 apartments, mostly studios and one- and two-bedroom units, although there are some three- and four-bedroom apartments and penthouses. Since leasing began, applications from 60 potential tenants have been taken, said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager at the Rockrose Development Corporation of Manhattan, the developer.

headline.main: Residential Real Estate; Another Building in Wall St. Area Becomes Housing

docs.abstract: Former office building at 99 John Street opens as apartment house after $76 million renovation; Rockrose Development Corp is developer of 28-story Art Deco structure, which contains 442 apartments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Humana Inc. reported today that it had sharply lower first-quarter earnings because of higher medical care expenses. It also announced a $15 million tentative agreement to settle Federal claims that Humana benefited from Medicare premium overpayments earlier this decade. The managed health care company had warned last month that its results would fail to meet expectations.

headline.main: Humana Posts Lower Earnings for Quarter

docs.abstract: Humana Inc says first-quarter earnings were sharply lower; reports earnings of $33 million, down from $50 million a year ago; also announces $15 million tentative agreement to settle Federal claims that Humana benefited from Medicare premium overpayments earlier this decade (S)
docs.snippet: Humana Inc. reported today that it had sharply lower first-quarter earnings because of higher medical care expenses. It also announced a $15 million tentative agreement to settle Federal claims that Humana benefited from Medicare premium overpayments...

docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors yesterday announced the indictments of six former officials of a large New York City union local, who are accused of stealing $2.7 million in union money, including $78,000 that was used for Super Bowl tickets and more than $10,000 for topless clubs. District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said that Charles Hughes, former president of the local representing school crossing guards and cafeteria workers, was accused of stealing more than $2 million.

headline.main: Ex-Officials Charged in Theft of $2.7 Million From Municipal Local

docs.abstract: Prosecutors announce indictments of six former officials of Local 372 of American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees union who are accused of stealing $2.7 million in union money, including $78,000 that was used for Super Bowl tickets and more than $10,000 for topless clubs; Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau says former local president Charles Hughes is accused of stealing more that $2 million; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fiscal knife that has begun to cut into teaching hospitals in Boston and other cities has not yet had the same dire effects -- layoffs or widespread operating deficits -- in hospitals around New York State. But hospital executives and health-care experts alike say that if the Federal cuts to Medicare are not softened, the state will lose much more than any other -- $5 billion and 23,000 medical jobs -- by 2002. And they warn that those cuts, a result of the Balanced Budget Act, pose a huge economic threat to New York, which has nation's greatest concentration of medical schools and teaching hospitals and trains about 15 percent of the nation's medical residents.

headline.main: New York Hospitals Braced for Cuts

docs.abstract: Fiscal knife that has begun to cut into teaching hospitals in Boston and other cities has not yet had same dire effects--layoffs or widespread operating deficits--in hospitals around New York State; hospital executives and health-care experts say that if Federal cuts to Medicare are not softened, state will lose much more than any other--$5 billion and 23,000 medical jobs--by 2002; say those cuts pose huge economic threat to New York, which has nation's greatest concentration of medical schools and teaching hospitals and trains about 15 percent of nation's medical residents (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Normally, the great teaching hospitals of this medical Mecca carry an air of white-coated, best-in-the-world arrogance, the kind of arrogance that comes of collecting Nobels, of snaring more Federal money for medical research than hospitals anywhere else, of attracting patients from the four corners of the earth. But not lately. Lately, their chief executives carry an air of pleading and alarm. They tend to cross the edges of their palms in an X that symbolizes the crossing of rising costs and dropping payments, especially Medicare payments. And to say they simply cannot go on losing money this way and remain the academic cream of American medicine.
docs.abstract: Teaching hospitals in Boston and elsewhere say that Federal cutback in Medicare spending has put such financial squeeze on them that it threatens their ability to fulfill their special missions: to handle sickest patients, act as incubators for new cures, treat poor people and train budding doctors; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Normally, the great teaching hospitals of this medical Mecca carry an air of white-coated, best-in-the-world arrogance, the kind of arrogance that comes of collecting Nobels, of snaring more Federal money for medical research than hospitals anywhere...

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Tenncare, the Tennessee health care program for the uninsured, misstated the number of people enrolled. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is 1.3 million, not 3 million. The article also misspelled the surname of the governor who established the program. He is Ned McWherter, not McWerter.

docs.lead_paragraph: No one had ever said that starting her own allergy practice would be easy, but Dr. Cheryl Lynn Walker was not prepared for the anxieties that beset her after she opened her doors to patients. ''I would get up in the morning, and I would just feel overwhelmed,'' she recalled.

headline.main: Doctors Face the Business of Medicine

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors ars studying business to help them cope with an environment in which managed care and corporate medicine now rule; feel they need to be as conversant in language of business as they are in healing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Looking out of the mist-covered window of his fourth floor office at Tufts-New England Medical Center here, Dr. Allen C. Steere inspected the urban sky on a warm spring day not long ago. ''More ticks,'' he warned gravely. ''If you have a mild winter and a warm, wet spring, those are good tick conditions.'' More ticks means more Lyme disease, which Dr. Steere has been studying for 24 years, longer than anyone else. In fact, he was the first to identify the brand new ailment among a baffling cluster of children with swollen knees in Lyme, Conn. And, over the protests of civic leaders, he gave it its name.

headline.main: Lyme Expert Developed Big Picture Of Tiny Tick
headline.kicker: SCIENTIST AT WORK: ALLEN C. STEERE

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Allen C Steere of Tufts School of Medicine, expert on Lyme disease; he gave disease its name and led research effort on Lymerix, preventive Lyme vaccine; has enraged many patients and their doctors by saying that Lyme disease has become a junk-drawer diagnosis, covering maladies from fibromyalgia to hypochondria; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vencor Inc., one of several troubled nursing home chains, missed a payment on its debt yesterday, providing new fodder for investor concerns about its ability to survive. The company, which said last month that its survival was an issue, said yesterday that it would not pay $14.8 million due in interest on $300 million of notes that mature in 2005.

headline.main: Vencor Misses Debt Payment, Raising Question of Its Survival

docs.abstract: Vencor Inc misses debt payment, raising question about its survival; Vencor says it will not pay $14.8 million due in interest on $300 million of notes that mature in 2005; company, battered by Medicare cutbacks and heavy financial losses, is trying to negotiate new terms from banks and Ventas Inc, real estate investment trust that retained almost all properties when Vencor split in two early last year; Medicare has demanded return of $90 million that Government says were overcharges; analysts say crux of problems at Vencor is refusal of a co-founder, W Bruce Lunsford, now Ventas chief executive, to reduce rents the company pays; one analyst notes Lunsford has strong reasons to keep Vencor afloat; says other nursing home operators would also insist on low rental terms because most of industry is struggling with cuts in Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: Vencor Inc., one of several troubled nursing home chains, missed a payment on its debt yesterday, providing new fodder for investor concerns about its ability to survive.    The company, which said last month that its survival was an issue, said...

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone perplexed by the amount of time Vice President Al Gore has recently devoted to traffic jams and suburban sprawl should consider this: Fifty years ago fewer than a quarter of Americans lived in the suburbs; now roughly half do. Every 10 years, another 10 members of Congress represent predominantly suburban districts. As the battle for the Presidency and control of Congress gets under way, that growth is having a more profound effect than ever before on the language and policy proposals of the parties. The focus ranges from education and child rearing, central to the family life that political consultants have identified as a suburban cornerstone, to the interest in controlling sprawl and a search for ways to appeal to the high-technology workers who populate office complexes along suburban beltways.

headline.main: Two Parties Seek to Exploit a Relentless Boom in the Suburbs

docs.abstract: Growth of suburbs is having more profound effect than ever before on language and policy proposals of Democratic and Republican parties as battle for Presidency and control of Congress gets under way; focus ranges from education and child rearing, central to family life that political consultants have identified as suburban cornerstone, to interest in controlling sprawl and search for ways to appeal to high-technology workers who populate office complexes along suburban beltways; photo (M)
